column1: Remark: At least one of the three specialisation specific courses must have been completed with a sufficient mark in order to enrol in the master thesis.

In order to graduate in the master Organizational Dynamics in the Digital Society at EUR, a student must write a master's thesis and complete it with a pass. The thesis (a scientific report resulting from empirical research) is intended as proof of scientific ability and is the crowning achievement of the scientific education. The course consists of two elements: the research proposal and the final thesis. Students cannot start conducting the actual research, before their research proposal has been officially approved by the first and second reader on Canvas. Both the research proposal and the thesis must be written in accordance with the APA guidelines.

Experience has shown that a good research proposal is a necessary condition to complete a master thesis of sufficient quality in the allocated time. Therefore, students are required to write a research proposal as a first product for their master thesis. The research proposal is a preparation for a number of important elements of their study, and contains an introduction communicating a research question and added value of the study, a summary of relevant literature and a rough, but plausible underpinning of hypotheses, preparation for the research method, an analysis plan, and a time schedule. The proposal should be written according to the APA guidelines. In consultation with the supervising lecturer, a student may start preparations for the research proposal before the actual starting date of the master thesis period, provided he or she meets the entrance requirements.

Students are expected to write a master thesis following the format of a scientific article. The thesis uses scientific knowledge and insights from the relevant disciplines (psychology, public administration and sociology). The thesis makes both a social and scientific contribution. Empirical material must be analyzed in a transparent and traceable manner, and above all, there must be scientific reflection on theory and practice. Furthermore, the master thesis must meet the usual requirements, such as a clear and systematic structure (introduction with problem definition, working method, theoretical framework, empirical analysis, results, conclusion, reflection), a clear and sound research design, rigorous data analyses, correct source indication, etc. (as described in the manual on Canvas ). Agreements about the content and the working method, the phases in the project, deadlines and partial products to be delivered are made in advance and recorded in the research proposal.

For their master thesis project, students can choose to work in thematic groups, which will be supervised by a teacher from Psychology, Public Administration or Sociology. Before the start of the course, the teachers involved in the master thesis supervision will indicate their subjects of expertise and interest, and put their thesis topics online from which students can choose. Students are also free to come up with subjects themselves. Students will be assigned to thematic thesis groups in Block 3. Their theses will share a common topic. A thematic group usually consists of 3 to 5 people who meet periodically. Thematic groups discuss the progress they made, whereby students present their work to each other and read and comment on each other's products. The aim is to create learning circles in such a way that students have a place to share experiences and support each other. If students work on their own topic, it may not be possible to assign them to a thematic group.

column1: <body>After completing the research proposal, the student can independently:

column2: • … translate a social development into a relevant problem for a scientific research;
• … indicate the theoretical contribution of the proposed research;
• … develop a research model based on theory;
• … propose a methodologically sound research method that is suitable for answering the research question and / or testing the hypotheses;
• … draw up an adequate analysis plan;
• … carefully consider the ethical and privacy implications of a scientific study.

column1: After completing the final thesis, the student can independently:

column2: • … formulate a relevant problem statement for a scientific research;
• ... use scientific literature to develop a theoretical framework and soundly underpin research hypotheses / research questions both theoretically and empirically;
• … conduct a methodologically sound scientific study;
• … analyze empirical material in a responsible manner;
• … link different empirical findings to theoretical concepts;
• … give a methodological justification for the choices in the research;
• … ethically justify the choices of the research;
• … formulate scientifically based conclusions in line with the research question;
• … formulate recommendations based on empirical findings and theoretical aspects;
• … give a personal reflection on the limitations of the own research;
• … independently write a research report according to scientific standards in the form of a scientific article.

column4: The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.

The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences);

cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings);

advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions;

intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender);
advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.
Students are able to:
<li>

column6: assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and  analyze and evaluate them;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences;

column5: <li>

column6: analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions;

column5: <li>

column6: work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role;

column5: <li>

column6: communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity;

column5: <li>

column6: keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy; independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Mundus MAPP includes a significant research training and independent research component, preparing students for further studies and/or jobs requiring research skills following graduation.

Work on the student’s research project starts with a short statement of thesis topic, submitted to ISS/CEU by 1 February of year one, stating a preference for a supervisor at the first year institution, who will act as primary supervisor in academic year one. In the following month, a second supervisor from York/IBEI will be allocated to the student, with this faculty member taking over primary supervisory responsibilities from the ISS/CEU supervisors when students progress from year 1 to 2. The two supervisors will collaborate and jointly advise the student during the two years of the program until the thesis is submitted.

The thesis report should be written after coursework finishes in the first academic year. The report serves as an advanced thesis proposal which already covers considerable ground for the thesis itself, to be written in year two. The report will be a paper of 6,000 words (including all references, footnotes, bibliography, appendices, and abstract), which includes a problem specification (research question/ rationale), initial literature review, methods and, where appropriate, hypotheses and case study selection; as well as work plan detailing deadlines the student intends to observe for writing up the different parts of the thesis. The topic of the thesis report (and by extension the thesis) should be relevant to the student’s mobility track.

The report is due by 1 September of year two, and is jointly graded by the two supervisors, each contributing half the final grade. Students receive detailed comments from the graders, and a single grade allocated in the ISS/CEU grading scheme.
The thesis report should achieve the following:

column5: Lead us into the general, then the specific topic.
Indicate that there is a gap, an area or puzzle that is unanswered or unresolved.
State the research question (as a question, where methodologically appropriate).
Indicate briefly how this question will be answered (i.e. what methods you have chosen).
Point to the value of this research, either practical (how it will benefit policy) or academic (how it will advance our knowledge).
Provide a review of relevant literature and indicate how it well help you deal with the chosen topic.
Provide a work plan with deadlines and deliverables up to the end of the thesis writing period.

column3: The thesis report will be marked in the ISS or CEU marking system, using the following assessment criteria:

column5: Problem specification: Is the research question to be pursued in the thesis clear and suitable?
Does the thesis report provide a convincing rationale for pursuing the proposed research?
Presentation of concepts / theory: Does the report identify a suitable approach/theoretical framework/key concepts that will guide the thesis?

Literature review: does the report identify relevant body/bodies of literature? Does it show a good understanding of appropriate/relevant literature? Is the literature competently reviewed, and its relevance for the thesis well established?

Research design and methods: Is the report explicit about the research design of the planned thesis, including, where appropriate, hypotheses and case study selection? Does it provide a good discussion of planned data collection and analysis, of sources and methods that will be used? Are the chosen method/s well justified?
Referencing: Is the use of literature and sources competent? Is referencing in line with good scholarly standards?
General presentation: Is the report neatly presented and clearly structured? Is the language clear and correct? Is the report within (and not significantly shorter than) the expected 6,000 words?
Quality of work plan: Does the thesis report include a realistic work plan and time table towards completion of the thesis, of the major milestones and deliverables?

column1: The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the GMD and PA courses in their track. The thesis must cover a governance issue in relation to migration and diversity, making use of the public administration literature to analyse a specific governance approach. For instance, a comparative analysis of how and why different countries or cities promote inter-ethnic contact, or an analysis of the impact of superdiversity on integration policymaking. Note that an internship is not part of our program.

The thesis trajectory consists of two parts: the thesis-proposal and the thesis-research. During this course [thesis-research] the students will execute the data-collection (where relevant) and analysis for the research question they formulated in the previous course and write their thesis in accordance to the academic standards. The process will be supervised in thesis circles where the proceedings are discussed with the supervisor and peers.

Students will be matched with a supervisor, most likely one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the GMD managing coordinator and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the process of conducting the research necessary to answer the research questions, and reporting on the study conducted, students learn:

column2: • to independently conduct the empirical analysis on secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using relevant methods and techniques;
• to independently draw and report academically sound conclusion(s) in relation to the research question and public administration and migration-literature;
• to reflect on the conclusion in terms of limitations, theoretical and/or practical implications, and the need for further research;
• to be able to clearly and adequately communicate the main findings of the study to both an expert and a lay audience.
• to clearly structure and fully reference a thesis.

column1: This MicroLab consists of two (online) sessions of half a day each. The sessions will be complemented with mandatory preparatory assignments on Canvas.

In the MicroLabs, the basic concepts are briefly explained, after which you actively apply the new information in cases, simulations and assignments. There is also room for reflection, discussion and peer feedback. This MicroLab will have multiple live sessions due to the coaching nature of the thesis supervision.

The MicroLabs are short how-to modules for EUR teachers on specific educational issues. They are developed by research and training institute Risbo and made possible by the Community for Learning & Innovation. Information on other MicroLabs can be found at https://www.eur.nl/en/about-eur/vision/community-learning-and-innovation/lecturer-training/microlabs. PhD candidates are encouraged to take other (non-credit bearing) MicroLabs depending on their needs.
Due to COVID-19, the sessions of the MicroLab will be online for the fall semester of 2020</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In order to complete the Master of Health Care Management, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HCM Master. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HCM staff. Each supervisor has between 4-6 students that conduct research on a specific theme related to the learning goals of the master HCM. Students may enroll in one of the thesis groups before starting their thesis trajectory. During block 3 through 6, group meetings will be organized -both supervised and unsupervised- during which progress as well as bottlenecks in the thesis process will be discussed.

The thesis trajectory is organized in one course: MSc Thesis. The thesis plan and thesis itself have a workload of 5 and 15 ECTS respectively and thus constitute a major part of the curriculum. The written thesis plan is graded by a PASS or NO PASS. A PASS for the thesis plan is required to start writing the thesis. The evaluation of both the thesis and the defence is conducted by the student's reading committee, which includes the supervisor and at least one co-reader. A pass of supervisor as well as the reading committee is required before the oral defence of the thesis. The written thesis and oral defence of the thesis should be awarded a minimal 5.5 grade.

column3: De master GMCS wordt afgerond en bekroond met een masterscriptie. De thesis vormt het bewijs van vakbekwaamheid bij het integreren van kennis, en het toepassen van kennis om de bestuurlijke complexiteit te begrijpen en er over te adviseren. De scriptie dient wetenschappelijk verantwoord te zijn. De student toont aan in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen onderzoeken en daarover helder te rapporteren. Het scriptieonderzoek wordt uitgevoerd bij een stageorganisatie. Tijdens de stage doen de studenten mee met het werk van de stageorganisatie, ontwikkelen zij een professionele werkhouding en voeren ze tegelijkertijd, in opdracht van hun tijdelijke werkgever, een onderzoek uit dat de basis vormt voor hun scriptie (zie ook de studiegidstekst voor het Atelier Professionele Vorming en de studiegidstekst voor de stage).

Het afstudeertraject wordt in seminars ondersteund. Deze seminars zijn opgenomen in het atelierprogramma. De scriptiebegeleiding vindt plaats in scriptiekringen van 3-5 studenten die verwante afstudeerprojecten doen. Elke afstudeerkring wordt begeleid door een docent. In principe moeten de scripties medio juli afgerond zijn om in september af te studeren.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

• zelfstandig (een) conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;

• een persoonlijke reflectie geven ten aanzien van het eigen onderzoek;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The canon of academic philosophy has increasingly come under scrutiny due to the ‘inclusivity question’. Taking the urgency of inclusivity as premised, what does it mean to make philosophical curricula more inclusive? Do we need to read primary texts by women, people of color, non-western thinkers? Do our teachers need to have diverse backgrounds? Do we need to change the norm of what good academic philosophy is so we can include non-canonical works?

In this course we will relay these questions by exploring how more inclusive themes are put on the philosophical agenda and in what way. In 20th century philosophy we have already seen Arendt juxtapose Heidegger’s notion of ‘thrownness’ in the world with a notion of ‘natality’. Foucault scrutinized the many institutional and discursive mechanisms that produce and sustain a heterosexual norm. Crenshaw taught us that ‘oppression’ means something very different to poor black women than it does to the middleclass white women that advocate ‘women’s liberation’. Likewise, in this course we focus on the lived themes of situatedness and response-ability, of bodily thought, of colonizing norms and of visionary futures.

Rather than linking these newly introduced philosophical themes to identities as e.g. woman, queer and/or black, in this course we tie these themes to lived experiences. In some lives, specific themes like natality are much more central and urgent than in other lives – than in the lives of many canonical philosophers. We will discuss examples of how some of the neglected themes that are embedded in lived experiences have been or are being included in philosophical practice, thus expanding the philosophical agenda.

This introduction of lived themes also results in problematizing a mainstream ‘style’ or ‘method’ of philosophizing – presumed that philosophical content and form entangle. Everyday concrete experiences, transdisciplinarity, fiction and bodily experiments for instance permeate this kind of philosophical work more often. In each lecture there will be explicit attention to the implications that thinking about a new theme has for how we think. In workshops we will experiment with these alternative styles of philosophizing.
At the end of the course, a workshop will be devoted to thinking about if and how students’ own lived experiences (could) motivate their philosophical research, notably in their BA thesis.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students are able to argue how lived experiences link to philosophical themes in four specific cases;
• Students are able to argue how lived experiences link to a philosophical style and/or method in four specific cases;
• Students can formulate how their own lived experiences motivate their philosophical interests and research;
• Students have tried their hand at several styles of philosophizing;
• Students are able to give arguments for choosing a specific style of philosophizing over other styles.

column1: Time series analysis concerns modelling sequential observations on economic variables, such as monthly unemployment figures. A suitable time series model can be used for making forecasts and for policy analysis. A key issue in developing a suitable model for time series concerns the dynamic features of economic variables, such as trends, seasonal fluctuations, and business cycles.
The main topics covered in this course are:

• Learn econometric techniques for modeling and forecasting economic time series data.
• Learn to apply time series models for describing and forecasting economic time series.
• Develop skills to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specificiation testing, and forecasting.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit vak geeft een inleiding in beschrijvende statistiek, waarschijnlijkheidsrekening en verklarende statistiek. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan toepassingen van de statistiek in de economie. Onderwerpen die aan de orde komen zijn beschrijvend-statistische maatstaven voor één variabele en de grafische voorstellingen ervan, samenhang tussen twee variabelen en lineaire regressie.

Onderwerpen uit de waarschijnlijkheidsrekening zijn kansrekening, de stelling van Bayes, verdelingen van kansvariabelen, waaronder de Poisson verdeling die een belangrijke rol speelt bij de analyse van wachttijdproblemen.

Verder wordt aandacht geschonken aan het schatten van het gemiddelde van een kwantitatieve variabele en aan het toetsen van hypothesen over dit gemiddelde zowel met als zonder een bekende standaarddeviatie. Ook komt een toets op het verschil in proporties aan de orde.
Tijdens de practica krijgen de studenten gelegenheid te werken aan opdrachten die betrekking hebben op de behandelde stof en die representatief zijn voor het examen.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Het ontwikkelen van een kritische beoordeling van het kwantitatieve denken in een zakelijke omgeving en economie.
• Ontwikkellen van een mogelijkheid om elementaire statistische methodologie toe te passen. In het bijzonder, in staat zijn om elementaire hypothesetesten uit te voeren.
• Ontwikkelen van het vermogen om betekenisvol statistische bevindingen te interpreteren in een bedrijfs- en economie setting.

column1: Dit vak vormt de brug tussen de voornamelijk beschrijvende statistiek (in FEB11005 - Toegepaste Statistiek 1) en het doen van zelfstandig wetenschappelijk onderzoek (bij FEB12012 Methoden en Technieken, FEB12013 Onderzoeksproject,  bij de werkcolleges, in de Master programma's, bij de scriptie, en later in de werkpraktijk).

Het vak behandelt statistische methoden en modellen die vaak worden toegepast in de economie, waarbij de juiste aanpak afhangt van de vraagstelling en van de aard van het beschikbare cijfermateriaal. De voornaamste onderwerpen zijn de volgende: toetsen, kruistabellen, ANOVA, niet-parametrische toetsen, regressie (enkelvoudig en meervoudig, tijdreeksen).
Bij de practica worden opdrachten gemaakt en besproken, waarbij practicumpunten vallen te verdienen. Studenten passen verder statistiek zelf actief toe met software.

column1: <body>Het vak bestaat uit twee onderdelen: personeelseconomie en publieke economie.

column2: • Het eerste deel van het vak bestudeert prikkels voor en motivatie van werknemers in organisaties. De rol van monetaire en niet-monetaire prikkels in het motiveren, selecteren en aantrekken van werknemers staat centraal. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn: de effecten van prestatiebeloning op de motivatie en selectie van werknemers, optimaal aanname- en doorstroombeleid, onderwijs, werken in teams, promotie-toernooien, pensioenen en andere secundaire arbeidsvoorwaarden.

• Het tweede deel van de cursus richt zich op het functioneren van markten in het geval van publieke goederen, externaliteiten, en asymmetrische informatie, en de rol van de overheid in het verminderen van de inefficiëntie die ontstaat wanneer markten niet perfect functioneren. De beperkingen van overheidsinterventies worden ook bestudeerd, evenals de effecten van belastingen en inkomensherverdeling. Tenslotte wordt de normatieve discussie van overheidsinterventie aangevuld met een positieve analyse van collectieve besluitvorming.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden met betrekking tot het werven, selecteren en motiveren van werknemers in organisaties.
Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden voor het bestuderen van het functioneren van markten bij markfalen en de gevolgen van overheidsingrijpen voor efficiëntie en verdeling.

Het toepassen van concepten en technieken die geleerd zijn bij de eerstejaarsvakken Micro-economie en Wiskunde 1 en 2 voor het analyseren van de effecten van voorgestelde reacties op problemen die besluitnemers tegen komen in de collectieve sector in het bijzonder en in organisaties in het algemeen.

column1: <body>In het vak Toga in Theorie en Praktijk staat een aantal thema’s centraal die als zodanig enerzijds voor de rechtspraktijk van groot belang zijn, en die zich anderzijds lenen voor academische bestudering, in het bijzonder vanuit het voor dit vak gekozen perspectief van de interne rechtsvergelijking tussen de drie hoofdgebieden van het Nederlandse recht. In dit vak zal in het bijzonder aandacht worden besteed aan de rol van partijen, bewijs, spoedprocedures, schadevergoeding, handhaving en alternatieven voor de klassieke procedure. In hoeverre onderscheiden de verschillende rechtsgebieden – na bestudering van de verschillende thema’s – zich van elkaar? Wie kan van wie wat leren? Of is het – vanwege de eigenheid van elk rechtsgebied – niet mogelijk om “best practices” uit te wisselen? Op dergelijke vragen zullen we samen met de studenten antwoord geven.</body>

column1: In this course we will focus on nonparametric statistics and kernel methods.

We are familiar with methods such as maximum likelihood or linear regression.  These are called parametric analysis as the data are assumed to come from a certain distribution (e.g., normal distribution) or have a certain relationship (e.g., linear relationship).  Nonparametric analysis intends to uncover patterns in data without such assumptions.  These methods are much more flexible and robust, but also come at a different cost.

Kernel is an essential concept in nonparametric statistics and helps facilitate many nonparametric methods.  It also has many applications in machine learning and allows to extend many basic methods into more flexible versions, such as kernel PCA and kernel SVM.

Other possible topics for this class include a review of cross validation, bootstrapping, reproducing kernel Hilbert space and semiparametric statistics, depending on the level of the class.  (To be decided later by the instructor)

The assessment will be based on the combination of two types of assignments.  There will be a mathematical written assignment every week following the lecture, and there will be 3-4 practical assignments where you need to programme and apply the methods on data.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding and interpreting theoretical measures of robustness (breakdown point and influence function)
• Imputing missing values such that the multivariate structure of the data is preserved
• Estimating standard errors taking into account the extra uncertainty from imputation
• Applying robust estimation methods that reduce the influence of outliers

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Introduce key concepts and problems in the philosophy of science.
• Develop the capacity of students to critically evaluate concepts and approaches in management science with regards to fundamental problems in the philosophy of science.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94006,2020,Trade Finance (& Banking) Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Businesses need to purchase goods and services, and those purchases need to be paid. In an international context, effecting a payment is not always straightforward. Therefore, this course looks at (international) payment mechanisms between the parties, including electronic fund transfers (EFT) and electronic currencies, at payment mechanisms involving third parties, such as bills of exchange, documentary collection, documentary credit, etc.

Also, companies may need financing, and thus banks, to be able to pay their purchases and working costs (like employees, energy contracts, etc.). In this course credit agreements like (subordinated) loans, overdraft facilities, revolving credit, credit lines, project & real estate financing, etc. will be discussed. Furthermore, we explore the rules and (ISDA)contracts on derivatives; swaps and futures.

The idea to obtain funds without collateral for the bank is a elysian thought. Hence, the course analyzes and evaluated security mechanisms such as liens and pledges, mortgages, bank guarantees, standby letters of credit, etc.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The purpose of this course is to familiarise students with the law regarding international payment services, financing and security mechanisms. Moreover, students learn about the legal aspects of payment and supply risks (e.g. currency and interest fluctuations, political instability, issues of non-payment, creditworthiness, etc); lack of funds or liquidity and how commercial banking provide services (payment services, commercial credit (as opposed to equity financing), factoring, etc) plus how to secure the risks (asking collateral and/or securities).

column1: This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Striving for self-improvement and self-transgression has always been an essential element of the human condition – from the myth of Prometheus, the Renaissance view on man as “the proud shaper of [his] own being” (Pico della Mirandola), to Nietzsche’s vision of the “Übermensch”. Today, important proponents of transhumanism are leading in different fields of the academic discourse, from the researchers of the “Future of Humanity Institute” at Oxford University, to prominent members of the tech elite such as Ray Kurzweil, Google’s director of engineering, or Elon Musk (Tesla, SpaceX). They propagate strong ideals of becoming “super-humans” and claim that the deficient human being ought to be transformed through technological and biomedical optimisation. Many transhumanists emphasize that they develop a new humanist philosophy, rooted in Enlightenment humanism and other historical sources. Most of them consider themselves members of a progressive movement with idealist goals, some have an explicit political agenda. Critiques argue that they foster an inhumane ideology, promoting ideals of the transhuman being as an output oriented, efficiently working high-performer. One could also say that a hetero white patriarchal is their model for human enhancement. However, some transhumanists are open for a “cyberpunk difference model” that is based on the ideal of unfolding human diversity through technology. Though some transhumanists regard human enhancement as a potential solution to the climate crisis another point of critique is directed against their anthropocentrism, promoting an unchallenged, dominating role of the human being as the master of nature.
This course will offer a critical, yet unbiased and philosophically sound discussion of transhumanist views and ideals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - You will be able to distinguish between different conceptions and ideals of transhuman or superhuman beings, to put these conceptions into a broader historical context of human self-understanding, and to critically discuss different ideals of being human or of transgressing the concept of humanity in view of future prospects and challenges.

- You will be enabled to critically discuss normative and ideological implications of different transhumanist views and ideals and to articulate your own philosophical position with respect to ideals of being (trans-)human.
- You will develop, carry out and assess the results of a collective thought experiment on the creation of superhuman beings – the “Perfect Human Enhancement Laboratory”.

column1: Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media-platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story (for a media product or consumer brand), allowing for a unified and coordinated entertainment experience, active audience engagement and eventually building a media franchise. What this means is that a story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics; its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth.

Transmedia is also 360 degrees marketing and public relations; allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from different angles and most importantly, enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself.

For students who are interested in subjects such as (corporate) communication(s), (communication, business and change) management, business development, marketing, public relations, branding, journalism, storytelling, entrepreneurship and the creative / cultural industries in general, the course presents valuable and indispensable insights in relation to current studies and latter professional activities.

In this course, we will follow the life cycle of two types of content: media texts and consumer brands by examining (marketing) texts and visual content; narrative structures; active audience engagement; integrated business models; franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies.

We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of this quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. In addition, we will look at alternative approaches to using Transmedia strategies for raising awareness about local, national and global causes, influencing citizen action and creating social impact.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: ·       The main theoretical approaches and perspectives to the study of Transmedia entertainment strategies;
·      The various ways by which Transmedia products affect the field of culture and entertainment;
·      The environment of transmedia stories with a particular emphasis upon issues of world building, fan productions, cultural attractors and narrative structures.
·      Examining how transmedia approaches contribute to key entertainment genres such as science fiction, fantasy, comics, television and games.
·       Examine how transmedia approaches lead to innovations in marketing genres such as PR, product placement and branding, advertisement, franchise and business development.
·       Examine the roles that media producers and consumers play in the creation, consumption and collaboration of media content or consumer brands;
·      Analyze the challenges and rewards that creating Transmedia products offer to audiences and media producers;
·      Critically analyze and reflect on practical issues in the field of Transmedia production;
·      Evaluate various marketing and advertising strategies related to media products or consumer brands;
·      Develop and pitch Transmedia strategies around an existing or a new media product or consumer brand;
·       Develop alternative uses of Transmedia strategies for local / national and/or global causes.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story for a media product or consumer brand or global/social issue. What this means is that the story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics; its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth. This facilitates unique entertainment experiences, active audience engagement and civic participation as well as builds successful media franchises.

Transmedia is also 360 degrees public relations: allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from all angles and most importantly enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself. Furthermore, transmedia strategies have also been highly successful as an alternative approach for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and civic participation as well as creating social impact.

In this course, we will follow the life cycle of different types of content: media texts, consumer brands, global/social campaigns etc. by examining commercial (webisodes, comics etc.) and grassroots (fan fiction, fan films etc.) texts; narrative structures; active audience engagement; integrated business models; franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies. We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks.

We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. In addition, we will look at alternative approaches to using Transmedia strategies for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and creating social impact.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column3: In this class, we investigate the making of heritage in both informal and formal educational settings. The focus will be on processes of heritagization of everyday material culture. Both in the academic field as in the wider heritage domain, there has been a growing interest in the culture of everyday life and ordinary things. Historians and ethnologists study the generational transmission and appropriation of repertoires of everyday material culture, and many museums develop exhibitions on everyday practices, displaying ordinary objects. Also in educational programmes for primary and secondary schools, a growing interest in the topic can be discerned. In the lectures and seminars the findings of historical and ethnological research, exhibition projects and educational programmes will be confronted with each other and discussed in a broader cultural context, with the aim of coming to a better understanding of different forms of heritage making and the role of education in processes of heritagization. A museum visit is part of this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can analyse processes of heritage making in various educational contexts (formal and informal, public and private) using ethnological methods and approaches
• Students can critically and analytically relate to academic and professional discourses on the dynamics of heritage
• Students can create their own vision on ethical and practical dilemma’s that heritage professionals are confronted with

column1: It is the main task of the Chief Financial Officer (CFO) to ensure that the firm has a sufficient amount of access to finance and to ensure financial stability over time. In order to reach this, the CFO is assisted by the Treasury Department. During this course, students are getting familiar with the different activities of the Treasury Department. These activities include cash management, working capital management, debt management, equity management, investment management and risk management. Cash management includes everything that  the treasurer does in order to ensure a stable cash position both now and in the future. Working capital management discusses the matching of the current assets and current liabilities to ensure a sufficient of liquidity. Debt and equity management discusses the several choices firms have to make when issuing debt or equity respectively. Investment management talks about the possibilities and choices that firms have when they want to invest today’s excess cash to ensure future income. Risk management discusses the several types of risk that firms are exposed to in their daily activities, such as exchange rate risks and interest risk.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course students should be able to:

»      Analyze and explain the (implications of) decisions that firms make with their available treasury;
»      Discuss and decide which financial actions should be taken when doing an important transaction;
»      Judge and analyze the decisions that firms make regarding their cash management, corporate finance and risk management;
»      Create a small business plan regarding a large investments vis-à-vis the company’s treasury position</body>

column1: <body>In this practical course, students will have an opportunity to learn directly from experienced forensic therapists. Each week, students will be presented with therapy options that received the most empirical support for specific diagnoses covered in the main part of the course. At the end of the practical course, students will be familiar with five different approaches to treatment, and will be equipt to understand the mechanisms behind all of them. By providing a wide spectrum of treatment options, students will also be equipped to make more informed decisions about their future education in psychotherapy.</body>

column1: The world of Data Science is buzzing with exciting innovations and daunting insights. In this extracurricular course, we will focus on understanding the underlying data generating process (DGP). As opposed to solely focusing on Deep Neural Networks, we will go through the process of Data Exploration and Transformation as well. After understanding the dataset at hand, we will introduce a diverse set of possible models. Every lecture will be accompanied by deepening resources. Students will select one group of models to apply to their dataset depending on the aim of the project. After Model Fitting, we discuss Model Validation where we again focus on the interpretability and validity of the model with respect to the underlying DGP.
Each session will consist of a 45 minute lecture, followed by practical coding examples.

• Students know the applicability of deep learning models and understand how they work;
• Students know the steps involved in working on a data science project from the data collection to implementation phase

column1: In this course we provide students with the art historical, theoretical and critical tools to come to terms with the artistic production – the visual arts, especially - of the post-war period. In doing so, students get a better understanding of both the arts and the contemporary. Throughout the course students combine theoretical discussions on the status of art (‘What is Art?’) and the nature of periodisation (‘what is the Contemporary?’) with critical analyses of singular artworks by canonical artists such as Duchamp and Warhol, Nam June Paik and Gerhard Richter, Jeff Koons and Damian Hirst as well as visits to galleries, museums and exhibitions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We probably all know children or students with learning disabilities. Perhaps you encounter problems with reading or math yourself. Nowadays it seems more important than ever to be able to do well in school, but unfortunately many children suffer from problems with learning. When we think of learning disabilities, most of us think immediately about dyslexia. However, there are many other learning disabilities. The focus of this course is on two forms of learning disabilities: dyslexia and dyscalculia. To be able to understand what happens with children with dyslexia and dyscalculia, it is of importance to learn about the ‘normal’ development of reading and math skills. During this course you will therefore read scientific literature on questions like: how can we explain dyslexia or dyscalculia? How can we predict reading proficiency or problems with math? We will also address questions like: what does the development of learning to read/to count look like and what does that mean for the instruction of these skills in school?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course you should be able to:

column2: • Reproduce and illustrate the cognitive development of reading and mathematical skills and the role of phonological awareness;
• Describe and compare different instructional methods to teach reading and mathematical skills;
• Explain the characteristics of two subgroups of learning disorders: (1) reading disorders, and (2) math disorders;
• Explain the underlying (risk)factors causing/predicting reading disorders, and math disorders but also normal development;
• Analyze the quality and use of assessment methods that are used to diagnose reading disorders, and math disorders;
• Analyze the quality and use of interventions and treatment of reading disorders, and math disorders.

column1: In this course, you will be introduced to what the SDGs and NUA are: how they came into being the basis for their development and what they are all about. The course provides a platform to question, analyse and reflect on what these policies are, how they relate to each other and how these policies contribute to current and future urban practices to ensure the development of equitable and sustainable cities.

column1: Politics is a defining feature of all human societies, yet it takes different expressions around the world. Because of its multi-facetted nature, politics is notoriously hard to define. How, then, can we analyse politics across different countries? Does it still make sense to talk about politics in terms of left and right? Does it matter whether you live in a kingdom or in a republic? How dangerous are populists, really? Can ordinary citizens really change the way they are governed?

This introductory course in comparative politics explores basic concepts of political science across a range of political systems. It will also familiarise you with comparative methodology: does political power lie with a president, prime minister or parliament, and why/how does that matter?

The core of the course will cover the most common political systems. You will learn how to distinguish between regime types, different electoral systems, and key aspects of political behaviour and culture. Finally, key issues structuring politics across the world will be examined: the role of ideology, populism, the relationship between democracy and authoritarianism.

Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

column2: • differentiate between a variety of political systems found across the world
• identify political actors and analyse their behaviour

column1: prof. dr. G. Liberali (EUR), dr. P.C. Schoonees (EUR)
Unsupervised & Reinforcement Machine Learning discusses unsupervised and reinforcement learning approaches often used to solve management science problems.
The first part focuses on unsupervised machine learning techniques for finding meaningful relations between all variables in a data set simultaneously. In contrast

to supervised machine learning, discussed in a previous course, in unsupervised techniques all variables play similar roles. Therefore, the relationships among all variables must be modelled, whereas in supervised learning only the relationships between the target variable and the features are of direct interest. An important application of unsupervised learning techniques in management is customer segmentation in targeted marketing.

The other main focus of this course is on reinforcement learning, where algorithms are used for sequential decision-making under uncertainty. Here, the focus will be on the design, solution, and implementation of reinforcement learning methods. Sequential decision problems involve a trade-off between exploitation (acting on the information already collected) and exploration (gathering more information). These problems arise in many important domains, ranging from online advertising, clinical trials, website optimization, marketing campaigningand revenue management.
An overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are:
• introduction to reinforcement learning and multi-armed bandits:
• Heuristics: one-step look ahead, regret policies, Thompson sampling
• multi-armed bandit modeling strategies and applications.
This course is a field course in the Tinbergen Institute program for 3 credits in the major econometrics.

column1: By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Understand the fundamental building blocks of unsupervised and reinforcement machine learning methods, with special attention to: principal components analysis, clustering techniques (k-means, hierarchical), multidimensional scaling, index-based solutions to multi-armed bandits, one-step look-ahead solutions to multi-armed bandits, Thompson sampling.
Program these methods by translating technical knowledge of a method into their own code in R.
Write a short report in the form of a scientific article.

column1: The aim of this course is to equip participants with a basic tool set that will capacitate them to work with data and interpret results for testing and refining theory as well as supporting evidence-based policy making.
More specifically, after following UDA students should have achieved the following learning objectives:

column2: • Understand what quantitative data analysis entails and how it differs from qualitative data analysis.
• Identify situations in which quantitative data analysis provides useful information in an urban context.
• Be able to use and explain the main tools of descriptive data analysis and visualization and apply these in practice using statistical software.
• Comprehend the power of random sampling and how to use that information for hypothesis testing.
• Understand the basics of regression analysis using the ordinary-least-squares method and apply the knowledge in practice using statistical software.
• Understand how quantitative data analysis output is interpreted, find meaning in the data, and learn how findings can be translated into policy recommendations and/or reflection on theory.

column1: <body>Urban Data Analytics (UDA) Qualitative course introduces urban qualitative research and focuses on qualitative data collection and analysis. Covering both theoretical and practical dimensions of conducting qualitative research, it helps the students to gain methodological skills to design and conduct qualitative research in urban settings. The course is structured around the following themes:

column2: • Introduction to Qualitative Urban Research (Qualitative vs. Quantitative Research, Sampling);
• Qualitative Data Collection Tools (Interviews, Focus Groups, Observations, Online and Offline Qualitative Data Collection);
• Qualitative Data Analysis (Types, Data Preparation and Coding, Presentation of Findings, Using Atlas TI).

column1: Together with UDA Quantitative and Research Design courses, this course provides students a practical guide for the design and implementation of their thesis research.

• The objective of the course is to help students gain methodological skills to design and conduct qualitative research.  At the end of the course, the students will be able to
• Understand theoretical and practical aspects of conducting qualitative urban research.
• Apply methodological skills on building qualitative research design, data collection and analysis of qualitative data.
• Apply ethical concerns, as well as concerns for validity and reliability in qualitative research.

column1: The course is divided into two modules that are taught in parallel:
Module 1: Urban Economic Development and Resilience

The first module covers the areas of urban economic development and resilience from a theoretical as well as an applied point of view. In the field of economic development, theories on urban and regional economics, and economic competition and competitiveness will be introduced. Discussions on inequality and entrepreneurship will round up this first part. In the field of economic resilience, participants will be exposed to the topics of evolutionary economics, sustainable and just economic transitions and innovation, and placed-based economic development policies such as urban labour markets.

Each topic will be covered by a lecture followed by workshops where participants will have the opportunity to discuss concepts and theories in small-scale groups, and to translate these into practical applications working together with their peers. The objective of module 1 is to gain comprehensive theoretical knowledge in the fields of economic development and resilience to be able to critically identify and evaluate local and global issues within urban economies, as well as to tackle these by providing workable solutions.

The second module will run in parallel and cover key methods of quantitative data analysis for policy evaluation. Specifically, participants will be introduced to the fundamentals of regression analysis. The major focus of this module lies in the interpretation of results, leading to evidence-based policy making.

Weekly lectures and workshops will introduce participants to both theory and practice. In each workshop, they will work with practice data sets using the statistical software STATA to translate knowledge into practice. The objective of module 2 is to gain solid skills and understanding of quantitative research methods for urban economic analysis with a focus on interpretation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The overall aim of the course is to gain insight into the fundamental urban and regional economic processes that explain sustainable economic development and resilience, as well as to develop the ability to analyse and govern these processes in practice.
More specifically, UEDR has the following objectives:

column2: • Reproduce and interpret theories that deal with urban and regional economic development and resilience in a sustainable manner.
• Identify criteria for urban and regional economic development using quantitative methods for evaluation.

• Apply economic and geographical reasoning to analyse sustainable economic development on various spatial scales: from countries and regions, and from neighbourhoods to households and individuals (macro-level, meso-level and micro-level analyses).
• Apply theories, concepts and analytical research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples.

column1: The master thesis is a crucial requirement for obtaining a MSc degree. It demonstrates the student’s ability to perform independent academic research study. With the aim of developing effective strategies for writing a thesis, various instructors specializing in research methodologies have been included as lecturers and facilitators for the workshop. The UCR research workshop is organized in three parts:

column2: • Introduction to the formulation of the research question and how to conduct a literature review, including lectures, discussions and presentations. The first part further includes two colloquia: one focusing on the research question of the thesis, and one focusing on the literature review.

• Usage of methodology, including lectures on survey design, data management and geographically weighted regressions. The second part is finalized with a colloquium on operationalization and methodology.
• Development of students’ analysis skills, finishing with a colloquium where students present their preliminary thesis results.

column1: By offering concrete strategies for an integral thesis writing process, the overall aim of this hands-on research workshop is to guide students in writing their master thesis. More specifically, the research workshop has the following objectives:
•          Start the research project and bring the research project into sharper focus.
•          Find and properly structure literature & come up with a conceptual framework.
•          Operationalize concepts into variables and indicators.
•          Analyze findings into a coherent and well-supported research study.

column1: This is a graduate course in Urban Economics. It treats several important topics in modern urban economics. Location and mobility decisions form the central organizing concepts to study cities, commuting, housing markets and real estate, and transport. After building up the urban framework, we examine agglomeration forces, long-run city development, and sustainability and energy efficiency in cities.
The course comes with a hands-on assignment that changes every year. The most recent assignment was from the city of Rotterdam, using large datasets to study spatial inequality.</body>

• To infer the value of amenities and property, based on information from house prices and wages and to comment on policies (transport, housing)
• To explain how cities develop in the long run
• To apply these insights to a real-life case and write a (concise) report

column1: Following the specialization period, the Urban Environment, Sustainability and Climate Change specialization will organize a Research Workshop to support the participants in the process of thesis development. The Research Workshop will consist of a series of methodological sessions specifically related to urban environment, sustainability and climate change issues, sessions to discuss different aspects and challenges related to developing a research proposal, and sessions in which the participants will receive feedback on their draft thesis.
The methodological sessions will include among others training on:

Other methodological sessions (e.g. project monitoring and evaluation, multiple case study comparative analysis, advanced data analysis approaches and techniques) may be arranged based on the specific research interests of the participants.
The sessions on developing a research proposal will focus on:

column2: • How to formulate researchable and focused questions

column1: In addition, four colloquia will be organized during which the participants will receive feedback on their thesis draft from the UESC staff as well as their peers. The first colloquium will focus on the presentation of the introductory chapter of the thesis including the research questions, the second colloquium will focus on the presentation of the literature review including the conceptual framework, the third colloquium will focus on the presentation of the research methodology including the operationalization of variables and indicators, and the fourth colloquium will focus on the presentation of data analysis including preliminary findings.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course is organized in 2 distinct modules. Urban governance: starts with an introduction to the complexity of the urban context and then focuses on the changing role of government and other key stakeholders in the governing of and decision making in a city. Students discuss and debate on the key theories that underpin different perspectives on urban governance. The module also looks at the role of local government in the context of decentralisation reforms, and the influences of these reforms on governance. Public Private Partnerships: introduces the concept of Public Private Partnerships (PPP’s) an instrument for urban governance. The students work on a practical case of business planning for PPPs, and use knowledge and skills gained to make key policy decisions on the appropriateness of PPPs in the urban context.

column2: • Urban Governance –this module looks at the nature of cities, and the increasing complexity in cities. It introduces the difference between government and governance, what urban governance is, and the trends in theory and practice on governance. The participants discuss why urban governance is an essential pillar of sustainable development and the different theories that underpin urban governance. Discussions revolve around the current academic debate on the utility of hierarchies versus new public management versus complex decision-making. Participants look at and assess the empirical evidence on both streams of theory and assess the extent to which these approaches have resulted in the outcomes intended at the local level.

• Public Private Partnerships – a mechanism to implement and institutionalize urban policy: Since the 1990’s PPP’s have become an important approach to streamlining cooperation and risk sharing between the public and private sectors, and achieving value for money in service provisions. This module introduces participants to different rationale, objectives and forms of PPP’s. Participants discuss and assess under what conditions PPP’s can be successful vehicles for urban governance and development. They apply a framework to analyse the 'marketability' of PPPs; this framework aids governments to make sound policy decisions related to PPPs.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After the module participants should be able to:

column2: • Differentiate the theories that underpin good governance; and understand the relevance of hierarchies, markets and network governance for urban governance.
• Deliberate on the trends in the nature of the urban context and its implications for governance.
• Distinguish the various forms of decentralization as an instrument of urban governance and analyse the impacts of the shift of power to local governments.
• Discuss, distinguish and debate the rationale for and utility of bureaucracies, vs. new public management vs. complex decision making in the complex world of today;
• Discuss the rationale for public private partnerships as a mechanism for good governance and understand the reasons for a shift to public private partnerships in service provision.
• Discuss the theories that underpins PPPs and understand what PPP’s are;
• Discuss and analyse how and under what conditions PPP’s can be used to institutionalize private sector participation in urban development.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Teaching method: Lectures and guided discussion; for the introduction and discussion of concepts and trends. Study groups and working groups: work in these groups will help, through reading and discussion, to deepen understanding of the literature and concepts used in the module. Evaluation: Students will be asked to write two short position papers, analysing some key readings. One will be written individually, the other as part of group work.  Final examination: The final exam will be a take home, open book paper   60 -40% The results of the exam will count for 60% of your final grade. Your performance on all exercises, will count for 40% of your grade  Peer evaluation: At the end of the UG module, participants will evaluate the contribution of their peers to the study groups and in the different group work done during the module.</body>

column1: The Lab is divided into three parts, with one part each in Blocks 1, 2 and 3.

In Block 1, the lecturers introduce: the objectives and format of the Lab; basic management tools and skills to be learned; and the simulation game. The simulation provides students with a first practical exposure to complex issues in an urban governance context. In this Block, students will introduce their personal learning goals related to the Lab, which will form one of the evaluation methods at the end of the Lab (using peer review based on Likert scales).

In Block 2, students work on four case study assignments, each of which takes one full day to complete: the assignment is explained in the morning and must be solved by the end of the day. The cases are undertaken in groups. Each case relates to a specific module in the course. In addition, each case tests a specific skill, for example: network analysis; achieving public policy objectives; learning skills; and policy innovations.

In Block 3, students will work on a real-life case for a Dutch municipality, centred on an actual policy question. On a first visit, students will visit the municipality, and municipal officials will explain the question and there will be an opportunity for questions and clarification. During a subsequent visit(s), students can do site research and meet with additional stakeholders if needed. After four days, students will present their findings and proposals to municipal officials. Students’ work will reflect the skills and concepts learned during the modules and the four previous cases in Block 2.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To increase practical abilities to cope with complexity, various actors and contexts.

• To present various ways of dealing with societal problems in a complex urban network system. Participants should be able to evaluate the various instruments they can put into practice and select proper action perspectives in view of the issues and contexts they are faced with.
• To use insights from other modules in the course and challenge the participants to use these models and approaches to analyse the cases presented and advise urban practitioners accordingly.
• To impart basic skills and tools, including co-operation, teamwork, negotiation, co-creating, and network-learning.

column1: <body>Teaching methods include games, group work and site visits to client municipality.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96134,2020,Urban Governance, Policy and Public Private Partnerships",Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,"['C Foley', 'C Lunetta', 'dipl.-ing. EP Petsani', 'dr. CB Pennink', 'EPAM Keunen', 'GT Nobre', 'R Warsen', 'S Sharma']",,"Inhoud
The course is organized in 4 different components:

column2: Urban Policy – policies for urban development: This component introduces the meaning of ‘policy’ and highlights various approaches towards urban policy. We look at what makes a policy “urban” as opposed to sectoral, the impact of changing concepts (for example, globalisation, decentralization, participation, neo-liberalism) and the influence of major actors on urban policy. We analyse what makes a good policy document.

Urban Governance – decision making in situations of complexity: In this component, we look at theories underpinning urban governance and focus on trends of network governance. Network governance is seen as an alternative to markets and rational choice (or hierarchy) and is designed for decision-making in a situation of increasing complexity, uncertainty and interdependency. Government is no longer the lead actor in development, but one amongst many. This implies a new role for government, a role in steering and managing horizontal relations.

Urban Planning - this component introduces the different meanings and interpretations of 'urban planning' and the urban planner. It highlights trends in planning approaches and zooms into the shift from traditional land use planning towards more strategic forms of planning.

Public Private Partnerships – a mechanism of governance: Since the 1990’s PPP’s have become an important approach to improving the provision of infrastructure and services in different sectors and achieving value for money in service provision. This component introduces participants to the rationale, objectives and forms of PPP’s. Participants discuss and deliberate on the conditions under which PPP’s can be a successful instrument for urban development.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After the module participants should be able to:

column2: • Discuss and describe the key characteristics of complex decision making and the problems associated with complexity; distinguish and compare network governance theory, new public management perspective and rational decision-making and discuss the implications of these differences for government; discuss and analyse the key characteristics of network governance theory; and analyse and apply the concept to practice in  a case study.

• Understand the meaning, dimensions and objectives of urban policy, understand the importance of the policy process and tools for implementation, discuss and deliberate on the nature of public interest and who determines it; understand the nature of policy analysis, and analyse policy documents using a set of guidelines.

• Reflect on what planning is and why it is useful; assess different planning approaches and explain what strategic planning is; analyse the implications of these different planning approaches for the role of the planner and other stakeholders in the planning process.

• Distinguish and discuss the different theories that underpin Public Private Partnerships (PPPs), discuss and identify the key characteristics of and the rationale for PPPs; identify, discuss and analyse the potential pros and cons of partnerships, as well as the issues faced in setting up PPPs in different sectors; distinguish various forms of PPPs and their characteristics.
• Understand the interconnections between the different module components and analyse what these linkages mean in practice;
• Within a multicultural team, jointly discuss and come to decisions that are mutually agreed upon.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92131,2020,Urban History: Rotterdam in Global Perspective,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. PT van de Laar'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The second half of the 19th century witnessed a period of rapid urbanization in Europe. The life of the city dweller, in particular in Europe, became economically, socially and economically dominant. This course orientates on the major transformations:
- Urbanization, the growth of cities and the shaping of the modern global city
- The port city as specific city (second city, shock city) and its relationship to the global city
- The planned modern city and ideal models on urban planning
- Cities as places of migration and superdiversity
- Urban visual culture, urban icons and the mediatisation of the city
- Urban heritage, public history and the role of the city museum

Rotterdam, originally one of the many typical Dutch commercial medieval cities, showed a spectacular growth in the 19th century. Rotterdam became the working city of the Randstad conurbation and turned into a world port after the Second World War. The modern urban history of Rotterdam – considered to be the most dynamic city of the Dutch metropolis since 1850 – is used as a case study to discuss the impact of 19th and 20th century urban transformations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Cities have played a significant role in the transformation of the world and today a majority of the world population lives in cities. Many scholars relate this urban revolution to a new round of globalisation. However, globalisation is a much longer-term historical process. This course focuses on 19th and 20th century’s urban transformation and gives an introduction on global urban history, using Rotterdam as a case study.</body>
