<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Addiction is an important problem at both societal as well as on the personal level. Only recently, addiction has been approach scientifically. Last 15 years there is a major international effort to acquire more knowledge about addiction. Through these international efforts we know a lot more about the mechanisms of addictive behaviors. Where addiction used to be seen as personal weakness, new insights within psychology, psychiatry and neuroscience have now clearly put addiction on the map as a psychological disorder, and not a flaw in the character. About time, because addiction is a disorder that is in the top 3 of most common psychological disorders. Recent developments do not only show there is progress in the theoretical aspect, but also in science-driven and effective treatments.

In this course the gap is bridged between the student and recent scientific insights. Different aspects of addiction will be discussed. Firstly, the background of the problem is described, such as the history, definitions and epidemiology of addiction.
In the second part, several theoretical perspectives are presented, namely the psychological and the neuropsychological models.
In the third part, the focus is on practice of treating addiction and addiction-related problems. Several different treatments are described and diagnostics will be discussed.

In the fourth part, behavioral addictions (such as gambling, game addiction and smoking) will be taught. During this course there is the opportunity to hear guest lecturers from the field (e.g., Bouman GGZ, Rottterdam), including an interview with a patient with an addiction.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course Addiction the student is able to:

column2: • Know the etiological and course aspects of addictive behaviors on both a psychological and neurobiological level;
• Diagnose addition problems (including behavioral addiction) and identify the vulnerability factors (including addiction markers);
• Make an argued choice for an addiction treatment using the knowledge of the different addiction treatment options, including motivational interviewing;
• To take a critical and argued position on societal, etiological and diagnostical aspects of substance use and behavioral addictions;

• Identify vulnerable periods during the life course regarding substance use, such as childhood and adolescence (including risk groups), and to name the relevant aspects of these for clinical practice;
• Explain addictive behaviors in the context of other co-morbid behaviors such as forensic and psychiatric problems;
• Make a  research question concerning addictive behavior and elaborate this in a research proposal and present it.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Economic agents often do not behave as the rational Homo Economicus. In behavioral economics the standard economic models and theories are adapted to incorporate the economically most relevant findings from psychology. Thereby, behavioral economic research strives to develop models with a higher predictive power than standard economic models. The challenge for behavioral economics is to maintain the balance between predictive power and complexity of the models.

This course will give an up-to-date overview of the most relevant behavioral economic models. Students will learn the differences between the various models. This will enable them to recognize which type of model is most appropriate in specific contexts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students learn the most common alternatives to standard economic decision models. Topics covered are decision making under uncertainty, decision making over time, and social preferences.
• Students learn to derive behavioural predictions from the decision models discussed.
• Students learn to recognize whether or not observed behaviour satisfies a particular model.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Over the past several decades, the dominant paradigm in financial research has been the rational expectations hypothesis based on the notion that investors and managers are generally rational. The rational expectations hypothesis leads to the efficient market hypothesis, which stipulates that asset prices incorporate all available information.

However, anecdotal evidence as well as theoretical and empirical research show that the rational expectations paradigm is insufficient to describe various characteristics of financial markets. Behavioral finance is another approach to studying financial markets. It argues that certain financial outcomes can be better explained and understood using models in which some agents are not fully rational.

This course examines how the insights of behavioral finance complement the traditional paradigm and sheds light on asset price determination, corporate finance decisions, and various Wall Street institutional practices. The course focuses on the application of behavioral finance to two main topics: corporate finance and investments.

Corporate finance aims to understand the financial decisions of companies and extensively deals with agency problems arising from the separation of ownership and control between shareholders and managers. In the course, we will study both the case in which rational managers interact with less than fully rational investors (e.g., in the context of market timing theories) as well as situations where managerial behaviour is less than fully rational (e.g., due to managerial overconfidence), and explore the implications for corporate financial decisions such as investments, M&A activity or capital structure.

Another fruitful application of the concepts of behavioral finance is to financial bubbles, defined as prolonged periods of rising prices to levels inconsistent with fundamental economic assessments. The rising prices are subsequently followed by sharp declines, sometimes even price crashes. During the course, we will analyse the conditions that create a bubble in experimental settings as well as review recent financial bubbles such as the Dot-com bubble or the U.S. housing bubble.

In the investments section of the course, we will study behavioral biases in individual investors' portfolio choices leading to insufficient or naive diversification, excessive trading, etc. Next to direct (stock) investments we will also look at issues related to the investment in mutual funds (e.g., return-chasing behaviour, mutual fund benchmark distortions), accounting for the fact that, nowadays, individuals invest the vast majority of their savings through financial institutions. The course may touch upon various other topics including the implications of behavioral biases among institutional asset managers, and the question of whether individual financial decisions can be improved through education.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the recent and rapidly expanding literature on behavioural finance.
• Students have understanding of how behavioural finance differs from traditional financial theory.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the effects of psychological biases on financial decision making.
• Students have knowledge of alternative methods to study financial decision making.
• Students are able to distinguish behavioural approaches to finance from traditional ones.
• Students are able to recognize behavioural biases in decision making, for both their own decisions and others.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100580,2021,Advanced Business Analysis and Valuation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SG Zori'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course ‘’Advanced Business Analysis and Valuation’’ builds on the relevant courses with a financial analysis component especially core courses on ‘’Business Analysis and Valuation” and “Financial Statement Analysis”. It deals with the more challenging aspects of financial analysis and valuation from an investor and analyst perspective. Thematic areas that will be covered in this course include:

column2: • Advanced Analysis and Valuation Tools: Introducing Equity versus Enterprise value methods; identifying enterprise value Multiples; accounting issues in enterprise value; forecasting earnings for enterprise value and Enterprise Free Cash Flows, Dividend Discount models, Economic Value Added; sum-of-the –parts valuation; Valuation Multiples; Adjusted Present values, Real Options in enterprise value; dealing with contingent claims character of equity and debt and valuation of private firms.

• Understanding Risk in Analysis and Valuation: Sources of risk; motives for risk management; Miller & Modigliani and risk management; hedging with financial instruments; accounting for derivative instruments; reflecting risk management in financial statements; dealing with risk management in equity valuation

• Applied Analysis & Valuation for Banks: Banking Business Models; regulatory background; financial statements for banks; controversial issues in reporting for banks; analysing bank performance; drivers of value creations; decomposing return on equity for banks; applying valuation methodologies for banks.

• Introduction to integrated Reporting, Sustainability, and value creation: Debates in managerial and finance theory about the way in which organizations and firms optimally communicate with their environment have been around for decades. Today the notion that organizations and firms need to adopt a broader view on performance measurement and reporting seems accepted by most. Various special interest groups, NGO’s, environmental organization, the public, but also institutional investors are making the case that organizations and firms should provide more disclosure about the positive and negative impacts on society, and therefore its sustainability. We would explore the role of sustainability reporting, disclosures and the effect it has on equity analysis.

column1: The course will have a strong practical emphasis and we will use many topical examples. In the first session, we will illustrate the use of multiple valuation methodologies in establishing asset values. We shall review the application of the methods discussed in prior core courses (Dividend Discount model [DDM], Discounted Cash Flow Models [DCF] as well as Earnings based models- Residual Income [RI]). We will then discover the many methods of valuation not covered in the prior course such as (Economic Value Added [EVA], multiples valuation, adjusted present values [APVs], Sum-of-the-parts and Real Option valuation models). We will touch upon valuing private firms and why private firm valuation may differ from valuing publicly listed firms. Key to success in this course will also be a thorough understanding of the accounting nuances that may cause difficulty in establishing value.

The risk management module includes discussions of risk management at US airlines as well as Airbus and Barrick Gold. In the banking module, we will discuss the business module of banks and debate the financial performance of banks and why they differ from non-financial firms’ valuation. In addition, we will take a closer look at the impact of regulation on banks and how that may impact bank valuation metrics. Given this strong practical component of the course, the general expectation is that students are up to date on recent developments in financial markets. An important part of the course will be class discussion, so your contribution is much appreciated. We will explore the full length of tools typically used in practical setting such as financial databases (Bloomberg, Factiva, Orbis, Thomson One, Thomson Reuters Datastream, Capital IQ) as well as newswires that might prove useful for your future careers.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: • Name the various components of financial statements eg. Statement of Comprehensive Income, Other Comprehensive Income, Statement of Financial position, Statement of cash flows, Statement of Changes in Equity and notes to the financial statement
• Define the main objectives of financial reporting
• Remember different accounting standards such as IFRS and US-GAAP
• Provide reasoned application of financial reporting in equity analysis to non-financial firms and Banks
• Recollect issues related to firms integrated reporting activities, disclosures and value creation process
• Interpret financial reporting information contained in IFRS or US-GAAP
• Estimate the value of firm using information provided in the financial statement
• Explore the link between the strategy of the firm, financial reporting, and value creation
• Explain integrated reporting, measurements and the landscape of sustainability reporting

• Apply various valuation methodologies such as Residual Income Model, Discounted Cash Flows, Discounted Dividends, Adjusted Present Values (APV) Relative valuation models and sum-of-the parts, and Real option Valuation models
• Demonstrate the use of different drivers of value in equity analysis and valuation such as Macro economic variables (interest rates, inflation, exchange rates, tax rates, commodity prices).
• Apply Integrated reporting frameworks and ESG in equity Analysis
• Analyze the effect of external factors in firm valuation eg. Credit analysis, cost of equity capital, cost of debt and WACC
• Analyze the effect of taxes, leverage, and credit on corporate value
• Appraise managements performance ( both Economic, Social and Governance) reflected in financial reporting and integrated reporting framework
• Judge the quality of managerial performance reflected in the corporate governance of the firm.
• Build your own valuation spread sheets reflecting valuation methods used and analysis undertaken
• Originate equity research reports containing a buy, sell, hold or neutral investment decisions

column1: As part of the PD track, the Advanced Business Communication skills course aims to develop students’ leadership and advanced business communication skills in challenging (international) work situations.

It will help students become more effective communicators in speaking and writing and is built on 4 pedagogical pillars: concept learning (theory), role-play (group), feedback discussions, and exposure to case studies and scenarios. It is fully workshop based with an emphasis on understanding personal and group communication styles and adapting/tailoring these to changing and challenging business situations.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99080,2021,Advanced Corporate Finance and Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['A Yang', 'prof.dr. P Verwijmeren', 'YS Gangaram-Panday']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The academic field of corporate finance examines the financial decisions made by business enterprises. An important part of corporate finance deals with the capital structure of the firm. Research on capital structure can provide tools to minimize the costs of obtaining financing for firms’ investments. The goal is to find the optimal mix of debt, equity and hybrid securities. Theories argue that firms choose between debt, equity, or hybrid securities to minimize costs that arise due to asymmetric information, agency problems, financial distress, and tax considerations.

Another important financial decision for firms is whether to engage in mergers. Researchers have attempted to answer whether mergers add value, and in which circumstances. There could be very good reasons for firms to do a takeover. On the other hand, agency problems might be able to explain why firms sometimes engage in mergers that destroy value.

Agency problems occur because, even though shareholders are the owners of many corporations, it are the managers that make the day-to-day decisions. Managers could have different incentives than shareholders. For example, managers might have a tendency to overinvest in mergers as this could increase their status and salary.

The difference in incentives between shareholders and managers highlights the importance of corporate governance. Corporate governance is the field in finance that deals with ways in which firms are governed and thus the extent to which investors can assure themselves that managers act in investors’ best interest. The interest in corporate governance has increased substantially after a number of accounting scandals in the 21st century, in which the financial results of firms were misrepresented. The goal of good corporate governance is to avoid (accounting) fraud and to increase firm value by assuring that managers only pursue value-creating investment opportunities. Setting an appropriate executive compensation package is an important part of corporate governance.

The first part of the course provides students with advanced knowledge in capital structure theories that build on taxes, financial distress, and agency costs (static tradeoff theory), information asymmetry (the pecking order theory), and market timing. The second part of the course describes the developments in mergers and in corporate governance. Several practice problems will be discussed and a business case will be worked on.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the theory and evidence on firms' optimal capital structure.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the value created by mergers and acquisitions.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: recent developments into academic research on capital structure and corporate governance.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: empirical evidence on illegal financial behaviour.
• Students are able to: critically assess firms' debt-equity ratios.
• Students are able to: critically assess firms' mergers and acquisitions.
• Students are able to: critically assess firms' corporate governance structure.
• Students are able to: analyze empirical studies in the field of corporate finance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course follows a problem-solving approach that synthesizes ideas from game theory, real options, and strategy for corporate decision-making. Corporate finance and corporate strategy have long been seen as different sides of the same coin. Though both focus on the same broad problem, investment decision-making, the gap between the two sides -- and between theory and practice -- remains large. This course synthesizes cutting-edge developments in corporate finance and related fields -- in particular, real options and game theory -- to help bridge this gap. The course covers a wide range of valuation examples, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, joint research ventures, product introductions, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment. The course will be given in close cooperation with people and organizations that are active in corporate finance, such as private equity investors, investment banks, and consultants. The course Corporate Finance and Strategy is structured in two modules. The first module introduces you to both traditional and new valuation principles for strategic investment. We review the basic concepts and foundations of the building blocks:
This part provides an overview and develops step-by-step the various principles useful for valuation and analysis. Questions addressed include amongst others:

column2: • How can one determine the value of a project or a firm?
• What is the value of a license that gives the firm an option to invest in commercial production of a new product?
• How is the optimal investment policy influenced by competition? How does competition affect the premium being paid in M&A?

column1: In the second module we discuss various applications and examples of private equity investment, acquisitions, and initial public offerings. Lectures by guest speakers will be an integral part of the course and provide an opportunity to become better acquainted with corporate finance in practice. This course provides the fundamentals for the seminar Advanced Corporate Finance and Private Equity.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into fundamental economic theories in corporate finance (real options, game theory and behavioral theory).
• Students have knowledge of different types of acquisitions and how they are structured and financed.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into strengths and weaknesses of using different types of valuation models, in the context where they can be applied.

• Students are able to apply valuation models in a variety of contexts, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment.
• Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the new structure we will illustrate applications, inspire, and motivate students, while the content is supported by digitization. We organized (sub) groups of smaller scale to support intensive forms of learning using case studies and assignments. We digitized this course with 3 types of webcasts for content and assignments.

1. For each week a 2D animation video provides an overview. In these animations we focus on the core of the course or of the lecture. Through the use of animations we simplify complex content and make it accessible to all students.

2. Advanced content videos provide in-depth content. These in-depth videos (varying between 5 and 10 minutes) can be used by students to prepare themselves for lectures and as a study preparation for the exam.

3. Assignment videos are useful as a preparation for question problems for the tutorials and as an exercise for the exam. Students can use these assignments to test their own knowledge and problem-solving skills. These assignment videos focus on difficult calculations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the centre of this course will be the recent advances in the development economics.
Topics discussed in class will include the role of human capital (health and education), access to financial services and the role of institutions in improving the lives of the poor.

Human capital is considered to be one of the most important determinants of economic growth and poverty reduction. Within the field of development economics several field experiments have been implemented to study how to improve access and demand of health care and attendance and performance of students in school. Also, the provision of financial services (credit, savings accounts, insurance) to poor people is a big challenge for the developing world. In the recent years, many countries experienced the ""microfinance revolution"", but access to formal savings accounts or insurance remains scarce. National and local institutions play an important role in shaping the economy and small changes can be crucial for improving the lives of many.
The final content and structure of the course will be discussed in the first session.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To understand current issues in development economics with a focus on how access to credit, health care and education can be improved in developing countries (microfinance and human capital).
• To study and present in groups at least one scientific article on a subject linked to the course.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The goal of this course is to learn how to analyze multivariate data. The course covers multivariate regression models (SUR), simultaneous equation models (identification and estimation), vector autoregressive models (cointegration) and parametric duration models (hazard models).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To learn how to do inference in multivariate regression and time series models.
• To be able to describe multivariate variables using multivariate econometric models and to do statistical inference in these models.
• To be able to work with multivariate regression models (SUR), simultaneous equation models (3SLS, GMM), vector autoregressive models (cointegration) and parametric duration models (hazard models).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102109,2021,Advanced Econometrics I,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. NW Koning'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. D. Fok (EUR), Dr C.S. Bos (VU)
Advanced Econometrics I covers the background Econometric Theory and a set of Micro-econometric models.

The course is built up around the book of Cameron & Trivedi, with references to the material of Hansen. The first four lectures discuss ordinary least squares and related methods, maximum likelihood, hypothesis and specification testing. They are followed by a discussion of the main micro-econometric models, including models for binary and multinomial outcomes, tobit and selection models, and finally models for duration data.

Theoretical exercises are discussed throughout this course. Concepts are illustrated by means of simulations and empirical applications. In class, the Python programming environment is used, though students are free to choose their own.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>By the end of this course, students will have gained a thorough understanding of the theory behind basic least squares estimation and inference, and the extension towards estimation through a likelihood function. They are able to apply this knowledge on micro-econometric models, and understand the consequences of modelling decisions. This will set the scene for the more general models and estimators to be covered in Advanced Econometrics II and III.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102110,2021,Advanced Econometrics II,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Pick'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. F. Kleibergen (UvA) and Dr A. Pick (EUR)

The course deals with causal inference, instrumental variables, generalized method of moments and likelihood based techniques. Modeling approaches, estimation and testing methods are developed. Asymptotic techniques and finite sample properties are discussed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Obtaining a deep understanding of econometric theory and the practice of producing econometric inference especially with respect to the specification, estimation, and testing of models for causal inference and for linear and nonlinear relationships by least-squares, instrumental variables and GMM or likelihood based techniques.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. H.P. Boswijk (UvA) and Prof. S.J. Koopman (VU)

Several major advances in time-series econometrics and likelihood-based inference have occurred in the past years. These advances have provided a major breakthrough in the modeling of time series using advanced up-to-date econometric methodologies. The first part of the course aims to provide a thorough understanding of linear time series models, including frequency domain analysis, multivariate models and co-integration. The second part focusses on state space models and the Kalman filter, discussing signal extraction, maximum likelihood estimation and dynamic factor models. The course will also discuss ARCH and score-driven volatility models. Various empirical illustrations in economics and finance will be discussed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students will receive a good training in time-series econometrics, the modeling of economic and financial time series using advanced techniques.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course begins with the illustration of the definition of the cultural industries, then it focuses on a general analysis of the economics of the firm and of markets (industrial organization) and of the institutional and policy framework in which the cultural industries operate. The course builds up to an economic analysis of technological change in the cultural industries and the implications for all types of stakeholders.
To ensure that all participants have a fair chance of performing well, all students must have passed an elementary course in the principles of microeconomics.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of this course is to develop students' understanding of the economics of the cultural industries. The course encourages students to apply economic analysis to an industry of their choice. Like any course in applied economics, this course stimulates students to use theory for developing logically consistent explanations of developments in the cultural industries and for making well-founded predictions. Successful students will also learn to appreciate the limitations of theory, explanation and predictions.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99955,2021,Advanced Economics of Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EMMP Loots'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ‘Advanced economics of arts and culture’ consists of lectures in cultural economics that articulate the application of the economic framework to the arts, culture, heritage and creative industries. The course relates economic principles and analyses to sectors such as the performing arts, visual arts, and the museum and heritage sectors, in which it investigates the role and activities of the main stakeholders: political decision-makers, policymakers, consumers, producers, patrons, etc. Topics under scope include: the rationale and instruments for public support; demand and supply of cultural goods; prices; the functioning of the art market; artists’ labour markets; the economics of cultural heritage; impact.

Note: This course is only open to BA students in Cultural Studies and exchange students with some basic knowledge of economics (e.g. high school level of economics). The lectures of this course are mandatory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of economics as it applies to the world of the arts and culture. Cultural economics studies economic decision-making by artists, organizations, policy-makers and consumers in the cultural sector. After the course, students will be able to evaluate the economic aspects of cultural policy and the market for cultural goods and services, based on economic theories about the arts, culture and creativity.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101253,2021,Advanced Economics of Regulation,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['KM Mikolajczyk, LLM', 'prof.dr. MG Faure, LL.M', 'prof.dr. NJ Philipsen']",,"Inhoud

This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides a thorough understanding of key results from the academic literature on optimal taxation. The course is largely normative in its scope, and addresses the following questions and more: What are the distortive costs of taxation? Should commodity taxes be differentiated? How should marginal income taxes vary with income? What is the optimal tax rate for top incomes? Should capital income be taxed? And if so, why? What is the role of taxation in a risky economic environment? What is the role of corporate income taxation? If the government can redistribute income with progressive taxes, is there still a role for other instruments such as the minimum wage? The course consists of two weekly Lectures that deal with the above questions in detail. Every Lecture has a dual goal: to provide students with a thorough understanding of theoretical underpinnings, and to discuss the practical implications, of the academic field of optimal taxation. At the end of the period, students’ understanding of the material will be tested by means of a final closed-book exam.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To gain knowledge on the principals of optimal taxation.
• To understand how taxes affect market outcomes, efficiency, the distribution of resources, and social welfare.
• To understand how taxes can optimally strike a balance between equity and efficiency.
• To apply the insights from optimal taxation to actual policy debates.
• To provide a reasoned, critical assessment of much of the tax system in the Netherlands (or any other country).
• To be able to derive and interpret simple rules for optimal policy.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102080,2021,Advanced Game Theory: Applications of Bargaining and Network Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr J.R. van den Brink (VU) and Dr H.E.D. Houba (VU)

Based on classic and recent articles, we discuss the development of game theoretic tools to analyze economic issues related to bargaining and network analysis. In that part on bargaining, strategic bargaining models of bilateral negotiations and endogenous threats (e.g. strikes or trade wars) are discussed. Several strategic bargaining models support well-known solutions in cooperative or axiomatic bargaining theory. The extension to multilateral negotiations of coalition formation with externalities is made to study endogenous coalition formation and the division of the gains from cooperation.

Time permitting, experimental studies of bargaining models are discussed. Cooperative solution concepts are also applied to explain endogenous coalition formation. In the part on network theory, game theoretic tools to analyze economic and social networks are introduced. We discuss allocation rules for various types of networks. Main attention will be given to communication networks and hierarchies. Finally, we apply these allocation rules to economic allocation problems with an implicit or explicit network structure such as water allocation, sequencing, assignment and auction games.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101952,2021,Advanced Health Economic Modelling,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. MJ Al', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'H Mokri', 'RJSD Heine, MA', 'V Qendri']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, such as decision trees and Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. In this advanced course, we will discuss e.g. more advanced model structures, survival analysis, model validation, finding cost and utility input for your model, and how to build a probabilistic sensitivity analysis into your model.
This course is essential for all students who aim to develop a cost-effectiveness model for their thesis.

During this course of 6 weeks, each week will be spent on a specific topic. A lecture will introduce the main elements of that week. In some weeks there will be a working group session where students can ask specific questions regarding that week’s assignment if they need so. In one week a computer exercise will be done to help students learn how to estimate and extrapolate survival curves from published data.

Subsequently, the excel-based models that were built by the students will be used for feedback sessions, to further develop modelling principles and skills. Two of these feedback sessions will be based on peer review, that is, each group will assess the models of two other groups, and report on them during the feedback session. The third feedback session will be based on model review of the faculty.
The exam is composed of four parts; the total of the individual parts and the total of the group parts both need to be a passing grade (5.5):
Only the final grade (100%) will be published in Osiris.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course should help you to get both more theoretical and more practical knowledge on cost-effectiveness modelling. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied, based on Markov modelling. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this. Models will be developed in groups of 3 students.
By the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • set up the framing of an economic evaluation.
• construct, populate and analyse a cost-effectiveness model using a Markov model.
• deliver a report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.
• discuss the strengths and limitations of the modelling approach taken.

column1: The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration.

The analysis of trade patterns and of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of households and firms. The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics.

The course focuses on the most recent and influential theories of international trade in a general equilibrium framework. The course finishes with computer simulations of these trade models to apply them to real world situations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration.
• The analysis of trade patterns and of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of households and firms.
• The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics. The course focuses on the most recent and influential theories of international trade within a general equilibrium framework.
• Students should understand the microeconomics foundations of general equilibrium trade theories, as well as applying them in computer simulations of real world situations.

column1: The following inventory control models will be covered in the course:

1. Single-location, single-item systems: standard (r,Q) and (s,S) policies with different demand distributions. Evaluation of service levels and costs. Optimization of policy parameters. Continuous and periodic review models. Deterministic and stochastic lead times.
2. Coordinated ordering: power-of-2 policies, joint replenishment model, production smoothing.
3. Multi-echelon systems: concepts and models, lot sizing, METRIC approach, guaranteed-service approach.

column1: A major part of this course will touch upon the field of Asset Pricing, especially in the lectures regarding the modeling of risk. A proper understanding of risk is fundamental to many financial management applications such as capital budgeting, risk management, portfolio selection and performance evaluation. Subjects include:

column2: • Basics of Portfolio Theory & CAPM: Normative vs. positive, assumptions, testable implications, pricing errors/kernel.
• Anomalies: Size, value, momentum & reversal anomalies, why use sorted portfolios.
• Return and return distributions: Expected return, non-normality, incorporating skewness and kurtosis, the role of expectations and information.
• Utility functions: First principles (nonsatiation, risk aversion, skewness preference), types of risk aversion, downside risk, Stochastic Dominance.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of theory on diversification.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into asset pricing models and anomalies.
• Students know how to construct optimal portfolios in mean-variance and non-mean-variance frameworks.
• Students are able to test for the existence of asset pricing anomalies.
• Students are able to conduct performance evaluation on investment portfolios.

column1: With respect to your previous classes in management accounting, this course offers a closer look into management accounting and control topics.

The Institute of Management Accountants (an U.S.-based institution) defines management accounting as ""a value-adding continuous improvement process of planning, designing, measuring and operating nonfinancial and financial information systems that guides management action, motivates behavior, and supports and creates the cultural values necessary to achieve an organization's strategic, tactical and operating objectives."" In accordance with the definition, we will examine various topics concerning management accounting and control discussed in literature and used by managers for decision management and decision control.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To broaden and deepen the knowledge of students gained during prior courses in Management Accounting.

• To understand (new) concepts, techniques and (external) forces influencing nowadays Management Accounting and Management Control. Interaction between practical cases and theoretical concepts is essential.

column1: Banks, insurers and pension funds feature daily in the financial press. The credit crisis has triggered a public debate on the risks, rewards and the costs of the banking, pension and insurance industry. Fundamental questions abound. Why do banks exist? Was it a good idea in 2008 to rescue Bear Stearns, the insurer AIG and let Lehman Brothers fail? What are the cost and benefits of bank supervision? Is there too much leverage in the system? Do financial conglomerates increase or lower the risks for the financial system? What about full reserve banking as an alternative for fractional reserve banking? How is the sector coping with the Corona crisis? What will be the effects of this new crisis in the longer run; will it turn into a financial crisis? We extensively discuss the role and risks of the financial industry and the connection with monetary policy.

This course addresses these kinds of questions by digging deeper. Due to asymmetric information it is difficult to match the supply of credit with the demand for credit. The financial services sector is the intermediary platform that helps to bridge the divide, albeit imperfectly. Due to the asymmetric information endemic to financial services, risk management is an integral part of the services. We discuss how financial institutions’ management, regulators and supervisors deal with the various risks they face. Risk management is analyzed on the level of an individual bank or insurer, and on the systems level. Bank runs can be devastating for the entire sector and the real economy. Regulation and supervision are thus an important aspect of the government interference with the financial sector. The interplay between monetary policy and banks is essential for the understanding the risks and behavior of the financial sector at a macro scale.

On the methodological side the course freely uses concepts from calculus such as elementary differentiation and integration rules and concepts from statistics such as distribution functions and densities, means, variances and the covariance. We also use concepts from micro economics, game theory (Nash equilibrium) and macro monetary economics.
The main topics of this course are:

column2: • The industrial organization view versus the asymmetric information paradigm
• Wholesale banking, relationship banking, asset based lending and adverse selection
• Bank fragility: Bank runs, systemic risk & diversification, regulation and supervision
• Monetary policy, interest rate risk and credit risk
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students understand the asymmetric information paradigm as the main explantion for the existence of financial services and the problem that this causes.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the risk management of a financial service provider and the systemic risk of the sector.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the interplay between monetary and macroeconomc policy.

• Students are able to: analyze the financial services industry using information economics and risk analysis. The students are able to analyze novel situations not treated in class, but using the class notes.
• Students are able to: analyze the interaction between the financial sector and the monetary economy.

column1: The course starts by introducing the fundamental data structures (e.g., arrays and lists) and complexity analysis for algorithms (using Big-Oh notation). After that, advanced data structures (e.g., stacks and queues) are discussed, followed by tree representations (e.g., search trees) and algorithms that allow to traverse them.
Students will have the opportunity to practice with the taught material by doing several assignments. All the course examples and exercises will be given for the Java programming language.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understand advanced data structures (e.g., stacks, queues, etc.) and tree representations and their associated algorithms.
• Be able to build data structures and algorithms in the Java programming language.

column1: The course starts by studying the concept of recursion and its relation to iteration. Then problems will be analyzed that are much easier to solve by recursion than iteration. After that we study several searching and sorting algorithms, and how to estimate and compare the performance of these algorithms. Several applications of these techniques will also be investigated.
Students will do individual assignments on the previously mentioned topics.

column1: This course is concerned with normative public economics. A choice is made each year from the following topics:

column2: • The theory of second-best and dead-weight loss
• Optimal taxes/subsidies on human capital and provision of education
• Optimal provision of public goods and social cost-benefit analysis

column1: The course links the optimal tax principles to actual policy discussions, for example, the flat-tax debate, the optimal progressivity of the income tax, the top rate of the income tax, taxation of capital incomes, greening the tax system, discussions on the optimal size of the public sector, the role of the government in (higher) education, etc.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To gain knowlegde of the principles of public finance.
• To learn to apply principles of public finance to policy questions like:
• How progressive should the income tax be?

column1: Should the government employ indirect taxes besides the income tax?
How should the government set the optimal capital tax?
How does taxation affect human capital investment and how does this affect the progression of the income tax?
How should the government internalize externalities, for example in the environment?
How much public goods should the government provide?
What is the marginal cost of public funds and how should second-best policy rules correct for tax distortions?

column2: • the optimal commodity tax and the debate on direct vs. indirect taxation
• the Samuelson rule for public goods provision
• To be able to derive and interpret simple optimal rules for optimal policies in second-best.

column1: To be able to apply many concepts from microeconomics and mathematics such as:

column2: • the envelope theorem and the implicit function theorem,
• maximization of functions with more than one variable
• using the Lagrangian method of constrained optimization
• models of consumer choice (consumption of various goods, the neoclassical labor supply model, and intertemporal choice.

• To be able to link principles of public finance to actual policy discussions, for example, the flat-tax debate, the optimal progressivity of the income tax, the top-rate of the income tax, the taxation of capital incomes, greening the tax system, discussions on the optimal size of the public sector, the role of the government in (higher) education, etc.
• To be able to conduct simple simulations of optimal public policies on the computer.

column1: This course thoroughly familiarizes students with the theoretical background of qualitative research and its main approaches, including discourse and semiotic analysis, in-depth interviews, focus groups and ethnographic fieldwork, and less traditional methods such as photovoice. It discusses the research process as organic and addresses advantages and disadvantages of the dynamic (and often unpredictable) nature of qualitative research. These discussions are grounded in in-class exercises and close-reading of published research, paying special attention to the flexibility of the analytical frame and the relation between theory and empirical data.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Qualitative research methods commonly used in social sciences
• Critically evaluate the application of these methods

column1: Students have developed skills to:

column2: • Formulate a relevant, qualitative research question within an appropriate research design
• Apply commonly used qualitative methods in a sound and creative way
• Report on their research design, application of methods and results of analysis (both orally and written)

column1: Advanced Quantitative Methods is het vervolg op Quantitative Methods (Kwantitatieve Methoden). In Quantitative Methods heb je kennis genomen van de rol van statistiek in wetenschappelijk onderzoek en technieken leren gebruiken om onderzoeksgegevens te beschrijven. Bovendien heb je t-toets, Chi-kwadraat toets, correlatie en bivariate regressie leren kennen. Advanced Quantitative Methods begint met een herhaling van bivariate en multivariate regressieanalyse en bouwt daarmee voort op de eerder verworven kennis. De technieken die behandeld worden zijn betrouwbaarheidsanalyse, factoranalyse, multivariate regressieanalyse en logistische regressieanalyse. Bovendien ligt er grote nadruk op hoe conceptuele modellen naar statistische analyses kunnen worden vertaald (controle, moderatie, mediatie) en de elaboratie van relaties tussen concepten (replicatie, uitleg, interpretatie, specificatie).

De kennis en vaardigheden vergaard in het vak Advanced Quantitative Methods zijn voor een overgroot gedeelte nodig om kwantitatieve analyses uit te voeren en daarmee je onderzoeksvragen te beantwoorden. Zowel in de colleges als ook in de computerpractica wordt bij het vak Advanced Quantitative Methods daarom nadruk gelegd op de rapportage en interpretatie van onderzoeksresultaten.

Het onderwijs wordt gegeven aan de hand van webcolleges, hoorcolleges en SPSS-practica. Thuis en in wekelijkse practica wordt in afgebakende opdrachten geoefend met de behandelde stof. In de webcolleges en hoorcolleges komen de verschillende technieken aan bod maar wordt ook het verband gelegd met de praktische toepassing ervan die in de SPSS-practica plaats vindt.

<body>This course provides an overview and understanding of the more commonly used and applied multivariate, statistical techniques and the skills to design, carry out and judge sophisticated, quantitative research projects. Specifically, the course covers statistical techniques needed for data reduction (scale and factor analysis), cross-sectional analyses (multiple linear and logistic regression analysis, path analysis) and for comparative analysis (time-series analysis, multilevel and meta-analysis). The course is 'advanced' in terms of concepts and methods, rather than statistical theory or mathematics. The focus is on real-world applications, discussing the assumptions, limitations and interpretations of a wide range of statistical techniques.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have advanced knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Key concepts and assumptions in the more commonly used quantitative methods, in particular multivariate statistical methods for complex data.
• How these statistical methods work and how their results should be interpreted.
• Formulate relevant research questions and answer these using appropriate statistical techniques (in particular multivariate statistical methods for complex data).
• Use these statistical methods in a sound and creative way, More specifically, they are able to clean and transform data, check for assumptions, conduct analyses, and interpret the output.
• Report on their research design, operationalization, execution of the data analysis, and outcomes of the data analysis and their implications in the light of a relevant research question.

column1: The course will be taught in English and is limited to 25 participants. Students are required to bring their own laptops to class (R and RStudio can be installed for free). The introductory R course is a prerequisite for this course. Exemptions from this requirement can be requested from the teacher of the course.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The open-source software environment R (www.R-project.org) is a powerful platform for data analysis and statistical graphics that has become the global standard in statistical computing. R houses an ever-growing extensive collection of tools for statistics and data analysis – an attractive basis for thorough exploration of your data. Furthermore, it provides a powerful programming language coupled with flexible graphical capabilities.

This follow-up to the introductory course will focus on programming in R. Basic programming concepts will be covered, such as accessing and altering parts of objects, controlling the order of computations, iteratively performing tasks using loops, and writing functions. We will also take a look at functional programming, and how to use these tools in practice.
Upon completion of the course, you will be able to use the power of R’s programming language for advanced analytic tasks to improve the quality of your research.

column1: There are two main educational goals of the ARM course. The first main educational goal of the ARM course is that you understand how management practice and research interrelate, and how high-quality research supports managerial decision-making. At the same time, you will also learn that all research, whether it is research executed by others, or research done by you yourself, has its limitations. A good understanding of such limitations, and a critical reflection on research help you to use research in managerial decision-making to become a force for positive change. The research cycle, depicted in Figure 1, shows the interplay between managerial problems and research.

The second main educational goal of this course is that you acquire the skills and the toolset that are necessary to successfully design and execute a research project within the specific research traditions of your chosen track. Management research can have a variety of shapes and forms, for instance in terms of the type(s) of data typically used in that field, the data collection methods used, and/or the data analysis methods used. Each track will explain what types of approaches are emphasized in their track this year. As foundations for such track-specific approaches, the ARM course will discuss the fundamentals and show the variety. Since the assessment of the ARM course is the same for all students, only these general fundamentals are assessed as part of the ARM course.
More specifically, after having finished this course, you should:

column2: • Understand the relationship between management and research.
• Articulate how to deliver quality in each of the steps of the research cycle.
• Explain how to collect literature, read academic literature, and critically synthesize academic and professional literature.
• Understand the wide variety in research approaches in management and know on which grounds to choose which approach(es).
• Understand the elements of a high-quality research project design.
• Know how to write a critical reflection on research.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Advanced Research Methods (ARM) course is first of all a methodology course that builds on the second year Research Project and prepares for the Bachelor Project. This course will:

column2: • Discuss the variety of approaches to research as a tool to help solve managerial problems.
• Teach approaches to critical synthesis of academic and professional literature.
• Provide a framework for critical reflection on research results.
• Teach how to use academic research as a tool to become a force for positive change in the world.

column1: IMPORTANT: Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for student who do have such background.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods. The focus is not on learning many new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but on interpreting and criticizing results, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture.

Workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where students practice the central element of the course: assessing the design, results and conclusions of existing successful and flawed studies. During the workgroup sessions, concepts and methods are applied after they have been introduced in on-campus and video lectures and in literature. Students prepare cases before each session and discuss them with fellow students and with teachers during the meetings. The work in these sessions leads up to the exam.

The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on studies that examine the use of language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography). In addition, attention will be given to the role of theory in qualitative research studies. In the final week students will present their full assessments of several published quantitative and qualitative studies.
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able

column2: • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory
• to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the direct results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational measures that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results

• to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences of this distinction for design and interpretation in specific situationsto recognize and evaluate different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis)

• to perform a discourse analysis of policy reports and to compare one’s own analysis with the analysis presented in a scientific publication to critically discuss the scientific quality of both analyses. to evaluate the role of theory in specific qualitative research studies by using the distinctions between gap spotting and problematization as well as between inductive and deductive reasoning
• to judge the quality of observations in ethnography by using nine observation dimensions
• to evaluate digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms
• to perform an ethnographic analysis and to compare one’s own analysis with the analysis presented in a scientific publication to critically discuss the scientific quality of both analyses.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: IMPORTANT: Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for student who do have such background.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods. The focus is not on learning many new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but on interpreting and criticizing results, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture.

Workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where students practice the central element of the course: assessing the design, results and conclusions of existing successful and flawed studies. During the workgroup sessions, concepts and methods are applied after they have been introduced in on-campus and video lectures and in literature. Students prepare cases before each session and discuss them with fellow students and with teachers during the meetings. The work in these sessions leads up to the exam.

The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on studies that examine the use of language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography). In addition, attention will be given to the role of theory in qualitative research studies. In the final week students will present their full assessments of several published quantitative and qualitative studies.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able

column2: • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory
• to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the direct results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational measures that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results

• to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences of this distinction for design and interpretation in specific situations
• to recognize and evaluate different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis)

• to perform a discourse analysis of policy reports and to compare one’s own analysis with the analysis presented in a scientific publication to critically discuss the scientific quality of both analyses. to evaluate the role of theory in specific qualitative research studies by using the distinctions between gap spotting and problematization as well as between inductive and deductive reasoning
• to judge the quality of observations in ethnography by using nine observation dimensions
• to evaluate digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms
• to perform an ethnographic analysis and to compare one’s own analysis with the analysis presented in a scientific publication to critically discuss the scientific quality of both analyses.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course traces the genealogy of individuation as a modality of entanglement. Modern social life and social theory are underpinned by a crucial but contingent ‘possessive individualism’. This course traces its origins as a way to doing social theory, i.e., as a way of asking how we might be together without the violence of extraction and domination. We will do so by way of readings of the histories of the commons, and by exploring Agamben’s concept of a form-of-life in the context of the late scholastic Poverty Dispute. We will try to see how modern capitalism and liberal political theory have their origins, in part, in a socialist conception of poverty and the common life. Liberalism still centers on an individuated conception of what the scholastic philosophers and theologians called dominium. In order to understand the ways modern capitalism and liberal political theory are born out of primitive accumulation, it is vital to understand both their emergence in and out of colonial domination and their gestation in the ongoing plunder of the commons by way of dominium, i.e., by private property. The course explores five alternative, non-individuated, conceptions of entanglement: form-of-life, the commons, the undercommons, incompleteness, and composition.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will be able to think and write about the history of individuation in relation to: a) the histories of the commons; b) the development of modern liberalism in tandem with the capitalist enclosure of the commons; c) the colonial divide  that marks modern liberal thought.
This course will comprise 3,75 EC for students from ESPhil.</body>

column1: Major theoretical concepts are examined and illustrated with a wide variety of classic as well as contemporary work. The course addresses questions such as: How does artistic practice
contribute to collective understandings and social solidarity? Is culture disposed toward cooperation or conflict? What fundamental transformations have come about in modern culture?

The content for this course includes fundamental readings from sociological theory which have shaped thought on art and culture. These theoretical areas include rational choice (Smith) conflict (Marx and Weber), functionalist (Durkheim), symbolic interactionist (Mead), and formal sociology (Simmel) are all explored as we engage in deep reading and discussion. Influential work that builds on this fundamental theory within the context of art and culture is also covered.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides an advanced theoretical overview of the sociological approach to art and

Culture. Through close reading and class discussion, the course aims to help students ground critical thinking in an understanding of seminal theoretical perspectives as well as understand both continuity and change in Western thinking about culture and society. By doing this students will be able to situate research within sociological thought and improve analytical and writing skills in dealing with challenging, abstract material.

column1: The advanced statistics course is about acquiring a robust understanding of advanced statistical methods and techniques for business analytics, in terms of both foundation and application. In addition, the course provides training in advanced programming skills, specifically using the statistical software R.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The learning objectives of this course are:

column2: • Understand and apply the main statistical concepts required for advanced statistical data analysis, e.g., central limit theorem, least squares, maximum likelihood, bootstrapping, hypothesis testing, multivariate analysis, functional transformations, and limited dependent variables.

• Understand and apply the main building blocks of a programming language, e.g., data structures, flow control, environments. Solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio
• Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders.
• Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, teamwork and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

column1: This course covers advanced topics in time series econometrics and forecasting, including:
The focus is on techniques that are found useful in applications to macroeconomic variables (such as output and inflation), and financial time series variables (asset returns and volatility).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Learn how these can be useful in various macroeconomic and financial applications; with a focus on business cycle analysis and modeling and forecasting asset returns and their volatilities and correlations.
• Learn how to deal with issues, both theoretical and empirical, that an econometrician working in these areas faces.
• Gain experience with actually implementing the studies techniques, learning how to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. H.P. Boswijk (UvA), Dr P. Gorgi (VU) and Prof. D.J. van Dijk (EUR)

The first part of this course covers nonlinear and non-Gaussian time series models, including models for discrete data with time-varying parameters and stochastic volatility models. We study estimation and inference methods, such as the extended Kalman filter and simulation-based methods.

The second part covers the formulation, estimation and testing of univariate and multivariate volatility models. We also discuss the use of high-frequency data in realized volatility measurement, and its use in volatility modelling.
The third part of the course covers non-linear regime-switching models, large-scale factor models, and forecast combination and evaluation.
For each topic, we discuss theoretical aspects of the models and methods. Real-data applications from economics and finance will show how the methods can be used in practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr A.J. Hummel  (UvA) and Dr B.A. Bruegemann (VU)

The content of the course is adjusted annually to pick up new topics from the macroeconomic research frontier. Each class meeting (after the first) has two parts. In the first hour, students discuss a frontier paper with the aim of identifying the main contribution of the paper, determining if this paper is convincing, and coming up with an idea for further research on the topic. In the remainder of the class, one of the instructors gives a lecture introducing the topic of the frontier paper of the following week.

To ensure high quality discussions for the frontier papers, it is important that you have thought about the paper before the class meeting. To make the preparation more fun and to give you opportunities to learn from each other, we will do this using a team-based learning approach. In the first week of the course we will form teams of 2 students that will remain fixed for the duration of the course. Each team prepares a brief presentation about the paper, and submits it before the class meeting. At the beginning of each class meeting, one randomly selected team will use its presentation to lead the discussion using its presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. be exposed to hot topics picked from the research frontier in macroeconomics
2. practice their ability to identify promising research questions
3. understand content that combines recent papers from the research frontier with advanced material that bridges the gap between the first-year macro sequence and the research frontier
Knowledge and understanding: Students deepen their understanding of the topics covered in the course by reading and discussing recent papers.
Application of knowledge and understanding: Students should be able to identify promising research questions. Where necessary, novel tools that are required to understand papers will be introduced.
Making judgements: Students judge the contribution of the papers that are covered during the discussion lecture, and of the paper they select for the referee report.
Communication: Students practice their (oral and verbal) communication skills by (i) presenting papers from the research frontier and (ii) by writing a referee report.
